entry.title: Never Update Your Name or Avatar Again

link.title: Never Update Your Name or Avatar Again

entry.content:
This morning, I woke up from three and a half hours of sleep after a long overnight shift, and decided I wanted to change some things on this site. The first thing I did was delete a bunch of fluff from the sidebars. The next thing I did was make some JavaScript that automatically updates my avatar and author name on posts (and other pages) with whatever Iâ€™m using on Mastodon, completely dynamically.

I put both JavaScript files into a repository on GitHub, along with an explanation on how to use them, here. No CORS headers or proxy servers required (this is a frequent problem with things I do here)!

Basically, what both scripts do, is simply read the meta tags from your profile, on Mastodon. All you have to do is make sure that you run these scripts in the head of your HTML, input your user profile into the top of the scripts, and then include each scriptâ€™s class in an < img > tag and an < a > tag.

And thatâ€™s it!

Now you can screw around and change your avatar and username on Mastodon, and any time you do that, itâ€™ll be updated on your website.

If giving the illusion that your website is federated with ActivityPub is something you enjoy doing, this is just one more way to do that.

entry.title: Bluesky Reaches 15 Million, Threads Gains 15 Million More

link.title: Bluesky Reaches 15 Million, Threads Gains 15 Million More

entry.content:
Before I have to go to work on a rare overnight shift, I wanted to write about the current social landscape, and less about some kind of perceived competition between Threads and Bluesky, and more about what it means to use these platforms. Obviously, there are reasons to be on Threads, Bluesky, and Mastodon, and for some, itâ€™s a race to the finish line, as to which one â€œwinsâ€ the main-character-social-media-site award.

But I donâ€™t believe either of the three options will ever be the â€œmain-line, main-characterâ€ choice. I think people will continue from this point forward, having specific things they want to accomplish and do online, and the place they go will depend on those very things.

Obviously, if you join Threads, youâ€™re probably a fan of Instagram, and youâ€™re looking to connect with, maybe, your audience, or something. And then thereâ€™s the ex-Twitter users spilling over, because, it is for sure something like Twitter.

Then you have Bluesky, the site thatâ€™s billing itself to be a Twitter replacement, gaining users rapidly, and there are definitely reasons you shouldnâ€™t build a site in order to be the next Twitter. But, there are caveats of Bluesky, in that, you can post your balls and ass, and you wonâ€™t get censored. And lots, and lots of people love to do that, on Bluesky, specifically.

And then thereâ€™s the community building, the list-making, and the large portion of LGBTQ+ users flocking to the site.

It could contend to be a place that doesnâ€™t suck.

And then you have Mastodon, basically, where everyone else goes. Linux enjoyers, and developers alike, especially. And one of the only social media places on the internet that isnâ€™t run by either a billionaire, or backed by some kind of venture capital.

But what does it mean to use the other two?

Obviously, Zuck is a billionaire, a billionaire who definitely has bad ideas, and bad opinions. On the flipside, like mentioned in one of my recent articles, Bluesky is backed by Bitcoin Capital, run by people who know Steven Bannon intimately. So, are you really ultimately in for anything different than what you were exposed to on Twitter?

Maybe, maybe not.

I do think, though, that itâ€™s becoming kind of muddy to say, â€œYou shouldnâ€™t use this, you should use that insteadâ€ because, as Iâ€™ve just mentioned, both Threads and Bluesky have issues with influence from â€¦ the darker side of politics, and the world.

Notice how I donâ€™t mention Mastodon, or ActivityPub in that, because AP is exactly what you make it. But, if Iâ€™ve learned anything, very many people want to sign up on something and then forget about it, forever. Which is not something you do on Mastodon. On Mastodon, you have to be an active participant, almost at all times in order for it to become something that you enjoy. And, letâ€™s face it, if you look at regular, normal users on Threads (for example), there are droves, and droves of people wholly uninterested in social participation, and more interested in a viral post thatâ€™ll make them an imaginary millionaire.

At this point, I donâ€™t think it matters too much what you use between the three, and fighting about it is a worthless endeavor. Bluesky and Threads are both connected to ActivityPub in different ways, anyway. So â€¦ you could say that Mastodon has already won this metaphorical social media war.

But, again, I donâ€™t think these things matter.

I do think you should consider your environment, and what the people who facilitate it believe, and say, on a regular basis. You should think critically about your participation online, be it via Threads, Bluesky, or even Mastodon.

And you most definitely shouldnâ€™t be on Twitter.

entry.title: My Joy For Gaming, Replaced By Endless Productivity

link.title: My Joy For Gaming, Replaced By Endless Productivity

entry.content:
I donâ€™t know when it happened, or even how it happened. But I know it did. I used to get home from work and spend most of my free time consuming another game. That was in my twenties, mostly, and also in the space of time that I was unemployed and suffering disability-levels of anxiety. But then something changed, and I became a machine.

Most days I come home from work, now, and I immediately load up VS Code and start typing. But before that it was music, and before that it was writing, and my Second Life store, or analyzing social media trying to figure out how to expand my audience. Why? Why do I now suddenly spend maybe five hours a week gaming, and the rest of my time just making things? I mean, I know why.

Itâ€™s partially my need, and want, to do something special, to do something people remember, or celebrate. But itâ€™s also my need for self fulfillment. I used to go to work, come home, and just do whatever, and be content with that, and always that. But Iâ€™m not content in that anymore.

I went to tech school in the middle of high school to learn to code. I wanted to be a full time web developer. I wanted to be sitting at a computer, analyzing networks, building more efficient web apps, and just â€¦ basking in the code. And that was stolen from me. I donâ€™t know if I stole it from myself, or if society pushed me into a place where I subconsciously deemed my lifelong dream career as secondary to what I needed to do in the here and now.

Except, weâ€™re at the now, and even through accomplishment, and self improvement, thereâ€™s still just more struggle.

It hardly even bothers me anymore that I might just be single the rest of my life. It bothers me more that Iâ€™ve been doing all of these things, and building websites, especially, since 19-frikken-99, and Iâ€™m â€¦ opening boxes for a retailer? Iâ€™m wearing a vest and driving into a big box store, and Iâ€™m clocking eight hours, and just going home, and thinking â€¦ is this the rest of my life?

I think the switch came on when I realized that it wasnâ€™t.

And now Iâ€™m terrified of stagnation.

Thatâ€™s the post. I donâ€™t really know how to remedy this, short of continuing to submit my resume to places hoping something sticks.

entry.title: Ten Months Without Windows
entry.content:
Iâ€™m sitting here a little more tired than Iâ€™d like to be, but thatâ€™s the life of working a manual labor day job, and code-jacking at night (what the hell is code-jacking). Today I want to sort of look back over the past year, and reflect on what itâ€™s been like to mostly abandon Windows (with a slight hiccup of returning for a week).

A lot of people panicked earlier in the year when Microsoft unveiled its AI powered â€œrecallâ€ feature, that screenshots virtually every single thing you do, and then stores it for uh â€¦ recalling later. The scary part is, or was, that you definitely should not trust a mega corporation with that kind of info. Even if they tell you not to worry.

And many rightfully made the plunge into Linux, and stayed there.

Thatâ€™s not why I abandoned Windows, though. I actually left Windows earlier than that, a couple months before the Recall announcement, when I decided that using a laptop for all the resource intensive things I do, â€¦ might not be a great idea sometimes.

Building a massive song in FL Studio with many, many layers can really lag out a system that isnâ€™t up to spec.

See, I have another PC (thatâ€™s quite dusty now) that I bought in 2018, that was entirely crowdfunded, so that I could do things I need to do in order to make money (at least at the time), and it was great. It helped me out a lot and I eventually dug myself out of a hole. The thing is â€¦ Microsoft is dropping support for Windows 10, next year. And it pissed me off, especially, because the processor in that PC is one generation behind what Windows 11 supports. And, because of that, I would have been stuck on Windows 10, without any security updates, or substantial system updates, forever.

I ultimately decided that this was enough of an insult to literally abandon Windows altogether, and forever (seemingly).

You know, and then they announced Recall, like 2 months later. Two months after I bought a massively powerful Linux PC from System 76.

And for months I used it under their flagship operating system, Pop!_OS. I got familiar with VS Code for web development. I moved all of my creative work to Linux, and I even got most of my games that I regularly play working, just fine.

But, like it does with me sometimes, I got this itch. I wanted to play some Call of Duty, and I definitely donâ€™t feel like running a console, when I have a PC with 64 gigs of ram, something like 15 cores, and 8 gigs of videoram. Doesnâ€™t make any sense.

So, I made a split decision, and installed Windows 11. And it was fine â€¦ for like a week.

But I noticed, even with all that power, Windows was â€¦ somehow laggy, and glitchy. Almost like my PC wasnâ€™t designed for it (or maybe I forgot to download System76 drivers).

Either way, I said, â€œYou know what, this isnâ€™t worth ONE game.â€ And I then installed one of my favorite Linux distributions, Debian.

Weâ€™re almost caught up to where I am now.

For about two more weeks, I used Debian, and then I noticed some â€¦ weird things, such as games blowing my fans up and my PC sounding like it was taking off into space.

It was then I realized, I need to update my firmware, and have system drivers from System 76.

Which, unfortunately, has almost virtually no existing documentation for Debian.

Enter: Now.

Iâ€™m back on Pop!_OS.

What a journey.

The reason I originally didnâ€™t immediately go back to Pop!_OS, was because Iâ€™m â€¦ kind of unsure of how Iâ€™ll react to my Gnome desktop being replaced by whatever it is they give me with COSMIC. But, fear of change aside, this OS is actually, or has actually, really grown on me.

And itâ€™s probably as close to Arch as Iâ€™ll ever get (thatâ€™s ragebait, Pop!_OS is nothing like Arch).

But, having spent most of the year in Linux, I think I can firmly call this OS my home. It feels natural. I enjoy opening the terminal. I like writing everything in code, even if I donâ€™t have to.

I am become system developer.

Whatever theyâ€™re constantly saying on /r/linuxsucks is at least, partially untrue (and also, I canâ€™t tell if these people are serious, or shitposting constantly). Itâ€™s not as complicated as they make it seem, but it is definitely more challenging than choosing a Mastodon instance.

You donâ€™t need to be a developer to use Linux, but it helps!

You can literally just, make a Debian bootable, or a Mint bootable, and then replace Windows, and continue using your PC like nothing happened. You donâ€™t even have to interact with the terminal. You can just use the graphical package manager thatâ€™s standard on, well, at least three Linux distributions Iâ€™ve tried (but whereâ€™s the fun in that?)

You can install Pop!_OS, and then Steam, and then continue your game in Dwarf Fortress just by switching on a little toggle in Steam user options that enables Proton support across every game you own.

Itâ€™s really that simple.

Just donâ€™t expect to play anything with kernel-level anti-cheat.

Which is probably actually a good thing. Why do game developers think theyâ€™re allowed to touch the kernel? Who the hell do you think you are? That dude from Scary Movie 2?

Suffice to say, I think Linux is where Iâ€™ll stay. As Windows becomes more and more bloated, and far, far away from the nostalgia of its greatness in 1995, Linux easily takes its place.

Now, watch this wholesome Debian presentation I found on Youtube.

entry.title: Bluesky Is Growing On Me
entry.content:
Iâ€™ve had some criticisms of Bluesky, ever since it opened. Albeit, I had some bad experiences with some users who seem to have also been chased off of the platform for the way they treat others. But, I also have been skeptical about its mode of decentralization (where is it?), and them being VC backed, and recently funded by a crypto company. But, things are changing â€¦

Theyâ€™re changing, because the social media landscape is changing. And I donâ€™t mean, â€œMusk took over Twitter, so we probably have to go somewhere elseâ€ in a means of changing, but more like, â€œAll corporate social media with lax moderation methods run by billionaires is probably a good idea to flee from.â€

And, for me, personally, looking at potentially everything becoming more expensive, and my bad experiences with being on Mastodon instances that arenâ€™t owned by me personally, Iâ€™m looking at what I may need to do in the future.

Donâ€™t get me wrong, I love the fediverse. But I have had to leave at least five different instances due to unjust banning, or extremely overzealous moderators who seek power in a digital space in order to a fill a void where they have none.

And for me, thatâ€™s a problem.

Iâ€™m a creator, I run a website, and now I also run a server with numerous scripts that showcase what I have, and can do. I run a digital â€œbusinessâ€ in Second Life, and Iâ€™m working simultaneously on an album and a novel. Iâ€™m a developer, a webmaster, a writer, and a sound designer, and I canâ€™t put my future, and potential future career in the hands of people who could silence me at a momentâ€™s notice, just because I, for example, said â€œfuck offâ€ to a troll.

Yeah, Iâ€™m still talking about the hackers.town incident.

Call me jaded, but I just donâ€™t know if I can trust admins of a fediverse instance to not screw me over, since this is something that has happened to me, over and over.

Now, thatâ€™s not to say Bluesky doesnâ€™t have methods of silencing people for no reason. They have public blocklists. But! What these blocklists canâ€™t do, is erase your entire online presence in a matter of minutes.

And thatâ€™s where I find myself at a theoretical future crossroads where, suddenly, maybe I canâ€™t pay 40 some dollars a month upkeep on my personal Mastodon instance, and I have to look at the alternatives.

Albeit, Wafrn, and Kitsunes.club are decent enough fediverse servers, and their admins havenâ€™t clobbered me out of existence (which would suck, because Iâ€™m also a partial admin/moderator on Wafrn), for one reason or another, they just feel like an extension of my online identity, rather than one thatâ€™s central. This isnâ€™t a criticism of either of these places, but more probably just me being â€¦ weird. I donâ€™t know. Owning my own Mastodon instance has given me a feeling of real control over how people interact with, and also perceive me online. And on something like Bluesky, I can sort of also achieve that, by forwarding my domain to my username, and redirecting my little bots to separate accounts (which Iâ€™ve already done).

The thing is, Iâ€™m probably way overthinking all of this, but in this bout of turmoil Iâ€™m experiencing, Bluesky has grown on me a bit. Iâ€™ve figured out how to use â€œfeedsâ€ to create my own â€œalgorithmâ€ and Iâ€™ve setup some placeholder moderation lists, and it feels â€¦ okay. It could feel alright, if, for some reason, I suddenly have to move there.

But â€¦ maybe I just havenâ€™t given Wafrn or Kitsunes enough of a chance to be central to my online identity.

What I do know, is that itâ€™s important to have control over your identity online, and to own your voice. To give the wrong people power over you in any regard, or facet, would be a mistake.
